text:
Welcome, everyone. Thank you for joining
us today from all around the world for what will
be a terrific conversation

with our special
guest, June Odongo, on how opening up learning
can close knowledge gaps.

My name is Chris Capozzola. And here at MIT, I'm our Senior
Associate Dean at Open Learning.

And this is the first in
a new open conversation series that focuses on the
experiences and impact of Open

Learning for empowering
people to improve their lives, communities,
and the world.

And as we set out to craft this
new open conversation series, one person we really wanted
to talk to is June Odongo.

June is an innovative
entrepreneur, a founder, and now the CEO of Senga Technologies, a
logistics software and services

company in Kenya, catering to
businesses that ship in Africa. Today, she'll share her insights
on learning, entrepreneurship,

and the role of open education
in upskilling and changing our world. So, June, thank you
so much for speaking

with me and our audience today. Your experience is
truly inspiring.

Thank you so much. I didn't know I was your first. Thank you. It's an honor. Yeah. Yeah. No, it's been great to hear
and learn about the work

that you've been doing
over the last few years. And I wanted to just
kick it off by asking you to tell us about your
personal learning journey.

Mm-hmm. Well, let me tell a little
bit about my background, which

actually connects somehow with
OCW So in terms of my education,

I have a computer science
degree from UMass Lowell, which is about 40 minutes
or so from MIT.

Many of my university
professors were actually MIT Computer Science graduates.

And I also have an MBA from
the Harvard Business School.

In terms of how I'd summarize
my learning journey, I mean, a combination of
formal education, as I've just

described, and then just
complementing my education

here and there. I think because of
these lecturers that I who had been at MIT and--

a lot of our coursework was
actually mimicking MIT classes. So when it came to studying-- And, by the way, I went
to-- if I can date myself,

I was in undergrad-- I graduated in 2005, so a long
time-- quite a long time ago.

And that's actually how I came
upon Open Learning, effectively

to complement what I knew the
MIT students were studying to help me perform better.

You started by taking some
courses on MIT OpenCourseWare, but you certainly
didn't stop, right?

And so you've
definitely been engaged in online learning,
continuous learning,

upskilling throughout
your career, even after sort of two
really significant degrees.

So what motivates
you to keep learning? You're a busy professional.

How do you make the time? Why is it important to you? I almost feel like
there's no choice.

I mean, like in our
company, for example, I mean, we're trying
to apply technology to some very complex computing
problems, I would say,

or mathematics
problems in logistics.

Also, by the way,
I should say this, I happen to be one
of those people who I apply so much
of what I learned

in uni, both in undergrad
and graduate school. Oftentimes, people
say, oh, whatever I learned I'm not using.
I am the exact opposite of that. So building on that is context.

The way we think about-- I think the way I mentally
think about problem-solving is

the same, but the context
is constantly changing. There's new ways of solving
some of the same problems.

Or if you're getting
to-- if you're encountering a new
problem, you need a new way to think about it.

And the solution can
either come from you, or you can borrow
from other people.

And if you're borrowing
from other people, it could be traditional. It could be new. And the way to get
that information

is to insert yourself into
materials, talking about how

other people are thinking
about these things, or even enhancing
your own knowledge if you're trying to come
up with your own solution.

So for me, I just think I
have absolutely no choice but to continue learning.

And in our company, we have-- our team members
are quite young.

Oftentimes, they're recent
university graduates.
I do not write software anymore. I used to. [LAUGHS] I just don't.

It was one of the
things, for example, I'm trying to do is we're
using languages that I didn't use when I was a student.

I think we used C or
something in computer science. They're using Ruby. I need to learn how
to use Ruby on Rails.

But more importantly,
we're also trying to apply technologies that
have advanced significantly

in the two decades since
I've been outside of school, whether it's things
around machine learning,

artificial
intelligence, and so on. So some of the work I have
to do in terms of learning is relearning what
I learned in school.

So I actually go through
some of my old curricula, and then introducing new
concepts on top of that.

So it's just embedded in-- I think learning
has to be embedded

in what we're trying to do and
what I'm trying to accomplish.

Yeah, that's a fantastic story. I think it reminds us
that the education that we

get with our degrees,
for those of us who have had the
opportunity to study, is sometimes a set
of concrete skills,

but it's really just an
investment in our future. If you don't keep
investing, right,

if you don't keep
watering the plant, it won't continue to grow.

That's really neat. So you've talked a
little bit about some of the work that
your company does,

Senga Technologies, and the ways
that technology and software

and software solutions
to logistics problems are part of the work that
everyone in your company does.

But you've also, in other
discussions that we've had,

sort of reflected that
it's been difficult to come by software developers-- to hire, recruit,
train, retain them.

And so tell us a little
bit more about how you've managed not only to
continue your own education,

but to build this up
for all the people who are part of your team.

So it's less an issue of
finding software developers because there are actually
plenty of them here, but more

about finding software
developers we can afford in an era where
software engineers are

such a hot commodity. And you bring them up, and
Google or Microsoft or whatever

comes and snaps them. So for us, it was
actually more-- the issue was more a
resource constraint.

When I started this
company initially, I was bootstrapping
it using my savings. And then when we
got initial funding,

it wasn't a super
substantial amount. So we've had to run a
really, really lean company.

And that meant we couldn't
afford senior developers and so on.

And then even if we
could, there's a-- because of how hot the
market was for engineers,

they likely wouldn't have
lasted because there's always somebody who can pay them more. So the approach I took was to
hire very high-potential younger

people-- so fresh computer
science graduates, folks who've been-- who
are just graduating or have

been out of school for
no more than three years. Yeah. So that was the
fundamental problem.

And then the way OCW actually
came into the Senga story-- it was not intentional at all.

So what happened was
there was a candidate who had been recommended
by one of our engineers.

She was an electrical engineer,
and she was very, very green.

And we initially
rejected her application. So her name is Cynthia.

And the person who had
recommended Cynthia is called Warren. So I go back to--

so I reject her, and she
doesn't say anything, much like how I used to
be when I was a candidate.

I don't take
rejection very well. [LAUGHS] Maybe-- I don't-- maybe
she was nonchalant.

Who knows? But, in any case, I
get back to Warren, and I'm like, hey, so this is
the feedback on your friend.

She's just too green. And he says, she's
really high potential. You need to just think
about that again.

So we go back, and
I talk to Cynthia. And she was working--

she was designing some kind
of hardware board somewhere. And I was like, OK, that's
pretty cool for someone

who's barely out of school. And I just-- and I thought,
OK, she was very, very bright.

What she didn't have was
a computer science degree, which for us is very, very
critical in our company

because we are
applying algorithms-- complicated algorithms
and complicated math.

And I just thought, well,
when I was a student, there was this
resource called OCW

that I used where
you could learn some of these things
that were complementary to these textbooks.

So I just suggested
to her, hey, you could join Senga if you're
willing to quit your job

and do this for six months. And I created a
curriculum for her which actually mimicked the
last two years of the computer

science program. And she said, yes. And then we ended
up finding this path

of bringing on board otherwise
talented individuals who,

for one reason or another, do
not have the education we need. So as of today, we've
got-- so Cynthia,
she did that program in 2020-- was it last year?
Maybe a little bit-- I think she started end of 2022.

No, no- end of 2023 because
this is her first full year, actually, as an
engineer at Senga.

And then we've since put
two other individuals through that program. The second person we
put through is actually

not a full university graduate. He's someone who comes from
an under-resourced background

but had the desire
to be an engineer, had gone to a coding boot camp. Coding bootcamps, for
us, do not give our folks

what they need, at least for
what works in our company. We put him through that. And then we've
since put in someone

else who has sort of
like a similar skill set. So we've been able to
complement our team.

So half our team is
from this program.

Wow. Yeah. Yeah. So that's really interesting. And that's exactly
the kind of story that makes us excited
at Open Learning.

It's the kind of thing that
motivates the staff who work here, and certainly,
the faculty at MIT who
share these materials. They don't have to do that. They don't get paid to do that.

They sort of sharing
these materials in order for other people to use them. Now, it sounds like
the special sauce

that comes from Senga
Technologies from June Odongo, is that--

is your work in identifying from
this big curriculum of materials exactly what's valuable for you
and your firm and your team.

So that's some
really amazing work. It does raise for
me another question.

I've taken courses,
watched videos and lectures from
OpenCourseWare, and some of them

are really hard. And some of those
problem sets that we share with the world
are really difficult.

So I'm curious, the
staff who you've kind of shared this
curriculum with,
do they think it's too hard? Do they think it's hard and fun? What's been their reaction.

It's hard. [LAUGHS] I mean, they're
very complex courses.

I mean, you know, networking
theory, algorithms.

I don't know if they
consider it fun. No one's told me
they find it fun.

But one thing that's
universal amongst them is that the amount
of learning they get

is so, so, so significant
just in a span of six months.

So I think they feel
better about themselves, in terms of what they're
capable, even from a learning

perspective, [INAUDIBLE]. There must be a moment in their
work, or even in your own,

where that light
bulb goes off, where you're just dealing with some
really tricky work problem.

And then suddenly, you realize
that you have the tools because

of a course that you took
through OpenCourseWare or something else, right? Mm-hmm.

You've reminded me of something. So the team member who
recommended Cynthia

was also mentoring her
during that process. And one of the courses is
something called automata--

I forgot the full
name of the course. And whatever problem he
was working on at the time,

he was like, oh, goodness. There something in
the automata class that he was helping Cynthia
with that he recognized

could help him solve a problem
that he was working on. Yeah. So it's almost like--

yeah, it's almost like this
extended hook in the learning.

It's not just for the person
who's going through it. Because what we
also do is we want

them to present to us something
at the end of the coursework

on some topic. So in Cynthia's case, for
example, it was graph theory. Could you tell us what you
learned in graph theory?

So what happens is there's a
re-learning also for someone like me. And then I remember
there's some algorithm--

I forget which
algorithm she presented. And I was like, oh, my God.

This is an insight I had in
terms of these kinds of nodes I was thinking
about in the network

design for the logistics. And I couldn't remember
that I had been taught this. I don't even know
if I was taught it.

But I was like-- it was very validating for
me because I'm like, oh, wow. I recognize something by
myself that isn't a textbook.
[LAUGHS] Yeah. No. It feels pretty great. [LAUGHS]

I love it. I love it. Ans that's a part of the joy
of teaching and learning.

And some of that happens
in the classroom, but it happens our whole lives. So let me turn now and ask
sort of a bigger question.

I've shared a
little bit about why MIT does this-- the
big so-what question.

And I want to hear
from you a little bit about the kind of impact
that you try to have.

I mean, you have not
just developed a company. You've also-- you've been
involved in and starting

nonprofits. You've been trying to make
an impact in the world.

And I wonder what advice you
would give to other people, to the younger
version of yourself,

or someone who's out there
today, for how they could-- how they can make a difference.

Hmm. I think the impact
question is big. I don't know what I would
tell my younger self.

But I think I can
think of what to tell other folks, which is for me,
there are certain kinds of--

the ideas or problems that
latch on to me so viscerally,

that I feel I have
no choice but to get involved in solving the problem
or addressing the problem.

And when I have that emotion,
I just pursue the emotion.

I think that's
behind the nonprofit. So the nonprofit we have is
called ZOO Memorial Foundation.

And what we do is we equip
community centers and schools

in very rural underserved places
with computers and computing education.

And that is linked to my dad. So my dad was an
electrical engineer. Unfortunately, he died
when I was quite young,

more than 20 years ago. But I would hear
stories of folks saying, oh, he showed me
my first computer.

Or the first time I touched
a computer was with your dad. Or he taught me
this or whatever. And I wanted to do something
to continue, let's call it,
his work. And that's how-- And a little tiny story.

I worked for this
company called EMC in Hopkinton, a data
storage company that's now acquired by Dell.

And it was Earth Day, and
they were recycling computers. Like, there was some email where
computers were being recycled.

And can I just say, I
was crying at my desk. I'd broken up with some person. And I see this email. I'm like, wait.

I stopped crying. And I'm like, I know what we
could do with those computers. And those computers end up-- long story short, we
end up kicking off

the nonprofit that way by
refurbishing these things. With the company,
in terms of how

I got interested in logistics,
I just was so frustrated. I was moving quite a
bit in a short period,

and just moving was so
awful And I was like, people have been moving
since time immemorial. Why does moving suck so much?

And I just got sucked
into logistics. Not that I had necessarily
a passion for logistics, but it was a nagging problem.

And then I'm also very big
on not regretting things. I'm very big on the
regret minimization thing.

So I tend to just ask
myself at any given point, if life ended
today, would this--

would I feel OK about
where my life has reached? And sometimes the answer is yes,
and sometimes the answer is no.

And I find it's yes
when I feel I've done something that
was meaningful to me and seen it through completion
or a good outcome or something

that could continue. And I find that it's no when
I'm in the middle of something. I'm like, oh, wait. I have this thing to do.

Yeah. So for me, I just move with what
grips me, I think, I would say.

Yeah. No, that's a fantastic story. I appreciate that-- those
kind of personal connections

that whether it's with a
family, with just a moment that hits you, that we
feel things, and then

we reach out and act on them
and build either as individuals

or with others. Is there a role
for open education

in moving from that visceral
feeling to the doing?

I mean, for sure. But I would just
add just one point to my earlier one is to
also just go for it, even

if you don't know how
it's going to end up. So in the story of the
nonprofit, what I did was I just wrote the company
back and I said,

could you give me
those computers? And then before I knew it, they
were interested in the idea. Then me and my colleagues were
refurbishing the computers,

and then they were
donating money. I just never foresaw that. I was like, give
me the computer. So folks should just start.

And then in terms of
with Open Learning. So after I-- at some point,
I think earlier in the year,

late last year, maybe
a year ago, I posted-- I did a LinkedIn post
about the coursework.

And the response was pretty
good in that folks said,

we didn't know we
could learn this way. Or can you show me where
I could complement this--

where I could mine
courses for my company? So a friend of
mine, for example, runs a rose farm in Kenya.

And she's in agriculture, so
her problems are different. And she asked if I could help
figure out how they could also

use Open Learning. And in her case, it's a company
of 800 people, many of them

are farm workers. So how one would think about
what kinds of lessons one

could glean from something
such as Open Learning is very different. It's a very, very wide scope.

So for me, I think it's pretty
applicable in just about every

scenario-- the classes
on how to think-- making decisions, for example. For me, I have
this deep interest

in behavioral economics, just
how one thinks about when you're

building technology,
but the behavior of folks, which is
always not how we think about things rationally.

Like, how do you
think about this? So for me, in almost
every setting,

I think somebody
can find something in Open Learning that's going
to complement that thinking,

whether it's
something pretty basic or something pretty advanced.

All right. OK. No, that's inspiring, and I'll
borrow that line-- just start.

We'll sort of-- I
think a lot of people will take that away
from our conversation. And speaking of all those other
people, it's time now, I think,

to pivot. And now I think it would
be a great chance for us to take some questions
from the audience.

All right. So, June, I wanted to just start
with one question that came in

from the audience from
one of our-- online from Mary, who was
listening in and hearing

about the ways in which
you've talked about how you've upskilled your workers and
yourself on the technical front.

But one thing that
Mary is asking is how or what
recommendations you

would have for
helping people develop their social skills
in communication,

in leadership, in networking? Have you found
resources to do that?

And have you done
that in your own work? And how have you helped
people in Senga Technologies do that as well?

Hmm. OK. So I think-- hi, Mary. First, thank you
for your question.

So for communication I think-- many of my colleagues
used to do Toastmasters,

and that worked for them. So if Toastmasters is
around you somewhere,

I would recommend
that because I think many people can write well or
communicate through writing.

And it sort of-- communicating verbally or in
public spaces or in meetings,

that tends to be difficult,
maybe because of confidence or that kind of a thing.

So I would recommend something
as simple as Toastmasters. Something that was useful
to me was learning tips

on something called
executive presence. I remember looking at
executive presence tips

very early in my career, things
like sit up when you're talking,

how you should stand
and things like that. For me, I found those to be
super, super, super valuable,

especially in the
early days when trying to establish my career.

For my team, I think the current
generation is facing, I think,

a different set of
communication problems, I think, than that we used to face. For us, it used to be a
lot about public speaking.

But I think because of
a lot of social media and so on, what I see commonly
is writing challenges, or being

very curt in writing-- very, very brief. So for our team, the thing
that I'm usually pushing on

is just written communication.  I don't like to see slides
or that sort of a thing.

I want someone to
express their idea in writing and with the correct
spelling and things like that.

And I will send it
back if it is not-- if it doesn't meet
that standard. Yeah.

So I think it just
depends on where someone is in their career, what
their background is and so on.

And just also observing. If there's someone who one
admires, who speaks well,

I think there's nothing
wrong in emulating that. Yeah. Yeah. No, I think that,
among other things,

one of our most popular videos
on MIT OpenCourseWare is from the late Professor Patrick
Winston entitled "How to Speak."

And it's been picked up millions
of times, millions of views. And I think it's just an
indication of the importance not

only of mastering technical
content or business content or other
things, but actually being able to express
it and to share it.

I'll look for it now. [LAUGHS] You had mentioned,
actually, the importance

of emulating a
public speaker as one path toward developing someone's
personal public speaking skills.

And that brings me
to another question. This came in from Rodrigo, who
has also a joined us an online

and sent this via
email, who asks, who was your most
influential professor?

So who most influenced
you as you were learning and whether that was in
the classroom or outside?

Hi, Rodrigo. Oh, that is a
difficult question.

I got along so well
with my professors. [LAUGHS] And even
professors in my school

who were not
teaching me directly. One of the people I think
who was most impactful to me was this guy called
Professor Moloney

who worked at EMC, which
I ended up joining. He was not my professor,
but we got along.

And then, I got an internship at
EMC that I ended up not taking.

And then I got a
full-time position. And I don't think I would
have gotten that without him

because I had not imagined
working for a company like that or an industry like that.

Yeah. I think Fred Martin is
someone who stands out to me. Oh, my goodness. He was an MIT Grad, actually.

I think now he is-- he might be dean of the CS
Department of University

of Texas at Austin. Yeah. So I didn't really enjoy very
much my hardware courses.

[LAUGHS] But he was my
professor, and he made it fun, and I did well.

And I think I purely did
well because he was great. Yeah. So yeah.

I don't know. I love academia. I love many people. So I really cannot
pick just one person.

I cannot. No, that's a great point. In many ways, part of
the joy of learning is learning from different
people in different ways.

And so sometimes there is one
individual teacher or professor who makes that huge
difference, but sometimes it's

the range of them that makes
all the difference in the world and why we need to keep learning
and keep finding new voices,

new mentors as we move in
different parts in our lives.

Nice. And so one thing-- another question
that has come in,

and I think this is really
important for a valuable-- sort of insight that might be
valuable to other people who

are looking to use MIT'S open
resources in training employees in their organization, which
is the question of assessing

the impact and the learning. So a lot of our
course offerings,

particularly on MIT
OpenCourseWare, they're open. They're self-paced. There's no sort of necessarily
metrics of whether you've

passed or failed. Our MITx courses do
have assessments. They do have certificates
for people who complete them.

But for you, as a manager and
as the CEO, how did you know?

How did you measure, or did you,
your employees when they were using MIT's open resources,
were mastering the material,

that they were
learning to apply it, and they actually
really were making a difference in their work. Mm-hmm.

Well, in our case, I
would say the measure--

there were three kinds of
measures, though I think one-- well, one is not-- [LAUGHS] I don't know
how useful it was,

which was do the
exercises in the course. Don't just listen
to the classes.

Do the exercises,
and then report. It was self-reporting, which
is why I don't know how-- I don't know what we
can say about that.

But self-report on
how you performed. Because at some point,
answers are given,

and you can see whether
you got something correct. So that was one. And then the second measure was
actually the pace of learning.

One can tell how one is doing
based on whether somebody

is taking too long or
something like that, just like what's going on. And then also asking
questions because we're

familiar with the material
because we are technologists. And then also, asking
the team member

who's going through it
to present on a key topic at the end of it.

So to present well, you
need to at least master at a theoretical level what
it is you're going to present.

Because we-- all of
us gather together, and you need to make a case.

And we're learning and
answering-- asking questions that we want answers from.

So those were some of
the ways to measure. And then the last one, I would
say, is just application.

Because our ultimate intention
is that the way of thinking

about a problem is reshaped. So then the proof
of the learning

is in the pudding, which
is your actual output once you start solving
problems within the team.

Yeah. No, I think-- And I just want to
add something on this. So one of my very
close friends is a--

I was about to say
he's a CTO, but he's now a CEO at this
financial technology firm

here that's doing really well. And he has helped recruit
just about every engineer in our company.

And we've been talking
about recruitment a lot because of these GPTs that
help people answer questions.

Once upon a time, you
could give a coding exam and you watch somebody do it And
now, somebody can do it online.

And then credentials,
like I've mentioned before, I think even
earlier in this chat, that having a computer science
degree is very important to us.

He challenged me on that,
actually, quite a bit. And he is someone who also
holds like a master's and--

a bachelor's and master's
in computer science. We're changing the way we
hire to test problem-solving.

And yeah. So it's actually no
longer about credentials because we have had experience,
and I think many employers have

had this, where folks can have
the most amazing credentials, and they still
can't do the work.

And what I'm finding
also is folks who are self-directed and
have a lot of deep interest--

and I this was true, too,
when I was an engineer myself. The best engineers
ended up being

folks who just, for whatever
reason, they chose that career, and they didn't
actually necessarily go

through a machine
like me for learning. For whatever reason, they
just had this deep passion,

and they opted in. And I think that's where some
things, such as Open Learning,

becomes very powerful. And actually, someone
added me on LinkedIn. And when I looked
at his profile,

he had switched his career
to finance or something just from Open Learning.

I literally just looked
at his profile yesterday-- complete switch of a career.
People see good work. People see good work. The world is changing.

It's hard to argue with
folks who work hard. Yeah. Yeah. No, I think those
are great points.

And I think the proof is
in the pudding, as you say. And I would also pull
out the importance

of knowing that
someone has learned it by having them present on it. They always say the best way to
learn something is to teach it

and to be able to
teach it to others. And also, that sort of
self-pacing, self-ownership.

So, in some ways you're
opening learning opportunities to people in your firm,
but it's really up to them

to track their
progress, to apply it. And that that's the best
way for them to learn it.

But I think the number one thing
I'll take from what you just said is that phrase "opt in,"
of just opting in to learning,

to curiosity is really key to
what it means to be an agile worker in the 21st century.

These technologies are
changing so rapidly. And that even the best degrees
won't last anyone for a lifetime

anymore, if they ever did.  So let's-- I want to switch
now to a little bit--

some of the questions
that have been coming in are really about and your
work and your journey.

So I'm going to turn some
